Subsequent to publication of this study, we obtained crystals that yielded slightly better diffraction data for the
). These data resulted in improved electron density maps and allowed us to identify and correct a fewerrors
in the previously deposited structure (originally deposited as PDB 6FPE). The latter (which is still available for download

1. The C-terminus of one of the TsaB copies in the asymmetric unit: amino acids 194–205 that were missing in the 6FPE

2. Modeling of a nucleotide bound at the active site of TsaD. We initially cautiously interpreted the residual electron density
by glycerol and PEG moieties present in the crystal freezing liquor. The new maps clearly showed that a nucleotide was

The new structure does not alter the primary conclusions of our manuscript:
The C-terminal part of the active site of
TsaD remains well-structured and is still capable of binding a nucleotide in
The AMPCPP occupies exactly the same position as the carboxy-AMP compound present in the recent structure of
). We further confir mtha ti nou rstructur eth eN-termina lpar to fthe
active site remains partially disordered and that neither Zn nor Fe ions are bound. This contrasts with the structure
, which has an ordered metal binding site occupied by Zn. This latter structure was obtained
in presence of ATP, and we suspect that the nature of the bound nucleotide (AMPCPP versus ATP) might play a role in
the metal binding. The two structures of the TsaBDE complex (6N9A and 6S84) represent probably different snapshots
